Even Xichen grows concerned, tells him‚Äî*lies to him*‚Äîthat it‚Äôs not a crime nor a sin to enjoy himself. A boy his age, he‚Äôs allowed to not be so strict on himself all the time. Pleasure, fun‚Äîthese are words Xichen uses, a foreign language that Lan Wangji is suddenly expected to know. More expectations placed on him. He is aware that even the most sturdy bow snaps under ill-applied pressure, strung with too tight a string. He is not a bow, though. Nor a boy. He is‚Äîhe is *Lan.* And he is lost. ---- ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji says, when there‚Äôs liquor. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji says, when he‚Äôs drunk. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says wildly, panicked, when Wei Wuxian‚Äîalso drunk‚Äîis just going to crawl in bed beside him, yawning. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says, more painfully, softly, when Wei Wuxian tries to leave. ‚ÄúLan Zhan, I have never known anybody more ridiculous than you are,‚Äù Wei Wuxian grumbles, but then does what he always does, finds the space between those two *no‚Äôs* and folds himself back down to sit on the floor by the bed. He unties his sash, his outer robe. He flings the sash away in the same motion that Lan Wangji bolts upright. ‚ÄúLan Zhan! *Calm down.*‚Äù Wei Wuxian rolls his eyes. ‚ÄúYou can have one or the other. You can have the bed, or you can have me fully dressed. Can‚Äôt have both.‚Äù He takes a swig from the jar, missing half of it with his mouth, wiping his mouth on his sleeve, which distracts Lan Wangji temporarily from the discarded sash. Wei Wuxian rolls his eyes again, placing both hands on Lan Wangji‚Äôs shoulders to ease him back down on the bed. ‚ÄúSee? More comfortable. Yes?‚Äù Wei Wuxian says in the patient way people speak to small children. He perches his chin on his hand, observing Lan Wangji for a moment. ‚ÄúAre you going to sleep now? Or call me Wei-gege again?‚Äù Lan Wangji‚Äôs ears blaze with heat. He can keep the color off his face if he stares up at the ceiling. ‚ÄúHmm,‚Äù Wei Wuxian muses. ‚ÄúNot harsh, but refreshing. Soft, yet full bodied. Mature and fragrant.‚Äù His eyes widen, happy to put on a display of innocence when Lan Wangji turns to look at him. ‚ÄúDescribing the liquor, Lan Zhan. You‚Äôre supposed to do that when you drink. All the poets do it.‚Äù Lan Wangji‚Äôs description would be *vile.* He keeps that thought to himself, returning to stare unblinking at the ceiling. He can sense instead of see the face Wei Wuxian makes‚Äîhis *Lan Zhan is so boring* face, a fact they‚Äôve well established‚Äîbut he is silent for a moment, which gives Lan Wangji‚Äôs question the chance to come tumbling out. ‚ÄúWhat else does one do when one drinks?‚Äù *Fun,* Xichen‚Äôs word, the language he is supposed to be learning. One might as well ask an expert. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says, taking it seriously. ‚ÄúDumb stuff. Laugh a lot‚Äîthings are funnier when you‚Äôre drunk. One time Jiang Cheng dared me to steal a boat, and I did, but it leaked, and we sank.‚Äù He grins to himself, basking in the memory, then shrugs with one shoulder. ‚ÄúYou just play around. Do what you want. Tease the boy you like.‚Äù Lan Wangji cuts his eyes at him. ‚ÄúKiss the boy you like.‚Äù Wei Wuxian takes a small sip of liquor. Lan Wangji feels the same jolt as when he walked in the room, the sudden little violent reaction at finding Wei Wuxian piled beneath the boys on the bed. Is this what he does when he drinks? Lose all inhibitions, let *someone else*‚Äî ‚ÄúLan Zhan?‚Äù Wei Wuxian says, amused. The silence has gone on too long. It is telling, because Wei Wuxian has set aside the jar and folded his arms on the bed, regarding Lan Wangji with interest. ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji says. The familiar response makes a smile bloom on Wei Wuxian‚Äôs face, warm and just as familiar. ‚ÄúOkay. Lan Zhan? Because you could,‚Äù he says patiently. ‚ÄúKiss me, I mean. Just as friends. I wouldn‚Äôt mind. I would‚Äî‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji says. It doesn‚Äôt sound like his voice. Wei Wuxian scoots up a little, propping up on his elbows. Lan Wangji, taken leave of all of his senses, responds without thinking, raising up on one arm to meet him. Wei Wuxian looks into his eyes. That lasts for several long moments. Then he is frowning, saying, ‚ÄúJust a little‚Ä¶‚Äù and tipping Lan Wangji‚Äôs head for him. Lan Wangji has already done something wrong, not known how to fit‚Äîwith their noses. Even drunk, he is lost, all the way outside the bounds of his meagre experience, unable to know what any sensible person would know how to do‚Äî The kiss happens then. Neatly, chastely. Lips are pressed against his. It is‚Äîdry, a little strange. Lan Wangji feels detached, unsure if he‚Äôs missed an important instruction. There is no precedent for it. *This is kissing,* occurs in the back of his mind. Wei Wuxian opens his eyes, pulling back. He looks‚Äînot *disappointed,* but doubtful. Lan Wangji has doubts too. He also has vast experience of the look on Wei Wuxian‚Äôs face when he sets his formidable mind against an unforeseen complication. Lan Wangji meets him partway that time, when Wei Wuxian leans back in. Better. Still chaste, still dry lips against lips, but Wei Wuxian has softened his mouth. Lan Wangji does the same, never one to let someone outmatch him. A string of soft kisses then, two, three, four, each one polite and studious. Lan Wangji makes a sound of dissatisfaction. Wei Wuxian shuffles up closer. He licks his lips, places his hand boldly on Lan Wangji‚Äôs chest, leans in and delivers what the kiss has been missing. This time it‚Äî*oh.* Lan Wangji‚Äôs lips part. He lifts up, chasing the kiss, a change of angle, and pressure‚Äîtheir lips slot together. It is wet now, and warm‚Äîan impossibly soft, silky heat that snags on his lips and spills down through him the way the liquor had done. *Kissing,* it‚Äôs‚Äîa little breathless, like drowning, or flying. Wei Wuxian climbs up closer; Lan Wangji‚Äôs hand slides around the nape of his neck. They both make a small sound at that, startled. The kiss grows more clumsy, more pressing, Wei Wuxian the one learning places his hands can go. It‚Äôs‚Äîthey pull apart. They pant a little, hands stuck in each others‚Äô hair. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt‚Äî!‚Äù Wei Wuxian protests, letting him go with an alacrity that makes Lan Wangji‚Äôs heart give a hard painful kick, until he realizes Wei Wuxian is staring at his ribbon, askew across his forehead. ‚ÄúRidiculous,‚Äù Lan Wangji says hoarsely, and pulls him back in. The kiss changes that time, again. Wei Wuxian is almost in his arms, and it makes awareness slide through them, of what exactly they‚Äôre doing. The kiss deepens, and slips, and then‚ÄîLan Wangji doesn‚Äôt even know quite how it happens. They‚Äôre still kissing‚Äîhis hand on Wei Wuxian‚Äôs chest‚Äîbut each kiss recedes, one by one. Like the tide going out. Safer kisses, softer kisses, circling around and arriving back at the polite, uncertain beginning. Lan Wangji lets him go, his hands empty when the last kiss breaks apart. ‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says, and clears his throat. ‚ÄúLan Zhan, that was‚Ä¶‚Äù He smiles a little, and rallies. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt bad. That was good.‚Äù He pats Lan Wangji‚Äôs chest, job well done, and musters a different smile for him, cheerful and obliging. He looks mussed and‚Äîwell-kissed, and unspeakably lovely, silver hairpiece askew, outer robe slipping down off his shoulder, his lower lip red where Lan Wangji bit and tugged it at the end. ‚ÄúAh, you can‚Äîyou can forget all about this in the morning,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says reassuringly, patting his chest again. ‚ÄúNever happened. I mean, I‚Äôll probably remember a little, just because it was‚Ä¶ and you‚Äôre‚Ä¶‚Äù Lan Wangji dies a little when he doesn‚Äôt finish that sentence. ‚ÄúBut I wouldn‚Äôt ever‚Äîjust two friends, drinking. Wouldn‚Äôt ever make you lose face. Promise, Lan Zhan. We don‚Äôt ever have to talk about it again.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji says, but the sound doesn‚Äôt quite come out. Wei Wuxian slips away, off the mattress, bedding himself down on the floor. His head appears again, too abruptly. ‚Äú*Aren‚Äôt* we friends now?‚Äù Lan Wangji, who is flat on his back again, staring fixedly at the ceiling, shakes his head. Wei Wuxian sighs. ‚ÄúThink we *are,*‚Äù he mumbles under his breath. ‚ÄúGave you my bed. Got you drunk. Had fun. Talked.‚Äù He sounds like he is counting on his fingers as he rattles this off, perversely leaving off *kissed.* ‚ÄúI do so much for you, Lan Zhan, and you don‚Äôt even say, ‚ÄòWei Ying, here, you‚Äôre so generous, you should have half of the bed, which is yours in the first place, I would not be so rude‚Äî‚Äô‚Äù ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù Lan Wangji finally manages to get the word out. ‚Äú*Fine.*‚Äù Wei Wuxian grunts, sounding suspiciously like he is grinning all over. There is too much noise as he shuffles around, fumbling and settling and trying to get comfortable. And then there is too much quiet. His head pops up again. ‚ÄúHey, Lan Zhan, I have books! Sometimes I read, when I can‚Äôt sleep‚Äî‚Äù ‚Äú*No,*‚Äù Lan Wangji says, so forcefully that there is no doubt this time about Wei Wuxian‚Äôs grin. He beams at him, draping his arm across the foot of the bed, the position in which he has apparently decided to sleep. ‚ÄúWhatever,‚Äù he says blithely, poking Lan Wangji‚Äôs ankle before he closes his eyes. ‚ÄúJust don‚Äôt complain at me in the morning, when you haven‚Äôt slept and have a headache so bad you can‚Äôt open your eyes, because you didn‚Äôt take my advice, and then everybody says, what‚Äôs wrong with Lan Zhan, usually he‚Äôs so mean but now he just looks adorable, I feel sorry for him, I think he must actually be a very nice person‚Ä¶‚Äù ---- It‚Äôs almost alarming, in hindsight, how little anything changes. Lan Wangji wakes up the next morning‚ÄîWei Wuxian doubled over laughing, trying to shake him awake, pull him up off the *floor*‚Äîmortification scalding the entire surface of Lan Wangji‚Äôs skin‚Äîbut none of it forces a reckoning, nor a major point of departure, nor a fork in the road from which he is unable to return. All of that happened weeks ago‚Äî*months.* That‚Äôs the truth that dawns on him through the course of the day. He has already discovered so much new terrain in himself that he just‚Ä¶ feels like himself. A little bitchy, a little terrified; miserable with longing and unrepentant and still utterly lost as to what he will do. Wei Wuxian doesn‚Äôt go anywhere. He squawks in protest at their punishment; he chases Lan Wangji through the cold springs. He is just like himself too, infuriating and loyal and‚Äîoddly quiet, robes dripping, watching Lan Wangji tie his ribbon around their wrists. *That* should feel strange, at least. New. A fundamental shift between them; instead, it feels like it has for the last half of the year, a fate that has stuck them together, half-wedded, half-doomed. None of it can last. This Lan Wangji knows. There is no future for them with Wei Wuxian happily ensconced at his side. He does not belong here, with three thousand rules and bitter soup served at mealtimes and the sour-faced, severe Second Jade who takes it as courtesy when his personality is described as merely aloof. This boy who calls his sword *Whatever.* This young man of grace, mischief, and beauty, too wild-hearted for the Gusu Lan to contain. Lan Wangji knows all of this, and still it slides into his heart like a blade, Wei Wuxian painting lanterns, pledging words about duty and justice, wishing to have a clear conscience all the days of his life. And that‚Äî*that* feels like a turning point. A thousand tiny fires trapped inside him,[^10] lifting up like the lanterns away from the mountain, into the sky. /private/cql/2-xuanwu-cave.content:
Seven days. Trapped in a cave. At the time, it doesn‚Äôt feel like those seven days could determine the course of his life, or Wei Wuxian‚Äôs. 

And yet. 

---- 

Lan Wangji wakes up to the sound of exertion. 

It has scarcely been a day; already he has learned that any sound in the cave is less alarming than silence. His leg keeps finding new ways to ache, which means he‚Äôs kept trying new ways to slip past the pain‚Äîdozing, mostly, outside of his habitual sleeping hours, or meditation so deep it might as well be unconsciousness. Wei Wuxian scolds him, saying how are they supposed to count the days if Lan Wangji sleeps at all hours, *so undisciplined, really,* and still it‚Äôs easy to slip in and out of consciousness, his body overtaxed and more broken than it has been in a while. 

That is one thing he‚Äôs woken up to, the scolding. There was also the snapping of twigs, Wei Wuxian yelping when he pinched a finger while feeding the fire. There was what first felt like silence‚Äîbut turned out to be the faint sound of water, Wei Wuxian coming up out of the pool to bring back a new layer of robes that he would have to spread out and dry. 

The actual silence, in which Lan Wangji basked for a single, decadent moment before he opened his eyes, had been Wei Wuxian an inch from his face, feathering a maple leaf over Lan Wangji‚Äôs skin. Wei Wuxian yelled and fell backwards, and then scolded Lan Wangji for so long that, eventually, the scolding helped calm the way Lan Wangji‚Äôs heart was trying to pound out of his chest.

So, the sound of exertion: a welcome thing. It gives Lan Wangji time to greet the pain in his leg, and to gather himself for the sight that awaits him. 

Wei Wuxian, on the other side of the fire, carefully moves through sword drills, testing his injured shoulder. 

He‚Äôs wearing the red inner robe, half-dry and streaked with the same dirt and soot that streaks his hands and his face. The sword, salvaged from a fallen Wen soldier, has no spiritual power behind it; it‚Äôs different from the way he wields Suibian with effortless grace. But he is still‚ÄîLan Wangji has the strength to admit this‚Äîan exceptionally skilled swordsman, an elegance and intensity to his movements that is arresting to watch. There is a kind of grace, Lan Wangji thinks, that is no less striking for the effort. Wei Wuxian wipes the hair out of his eyes and goes through the same drills again, and again, finally sheathing the sword with a grin of boundless delight when he catches Lan Wangji watching him. 

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre awake!‚Äù he says, dropping down beside Lan Wangji to poke at the fire. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting better. My shoulder.‚Äù He exhibits this range of motion, then rubs at his chest, wincing slightly. ‚ÄúNot that it really hurts but it‚Äôs good to keep stretching it out, make sure it heals properly. Shijie would make me eat lots of protein if I was at home, so my stomach keeps growling. Have you ever had lung fung soup? No, I guess not. It‚Äôs a Yunmeng dish. Or pork rib and lotus root? Nobody makes it like shijie. I‚Äôd get injured just to have it, it‚Äôs that good.‚Äù He rubs his stomach with a look of distress and longing. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs worse, to think about food or to not think about it. How‚Äôs your leg, with the medicine? I‚Äôll be ready to fight Xuanwu like we planned when you‚Äôre ready.‚Äù

Lan Wangji has followed this stream of talk the way he follows most things out of Wei Wuxian‚Äôs mouth, with effort and partial success. ‚ÄúMn,‚Äù he answers, to the one question he deems relevant.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says sincerely. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs from Wen Qing, so I knew it would help. You‚Äôll feel better, Lan Zhan, and then we‚Äôll fight Xuanwu, and if I die you have to tell everyone how brave I was.‚Äù 

He‚Äôs teasing. He flashes a smile so brilliant and full of life it says *how could I ever die?*

Lan Wangji, knowing better than to argue, says, ‚ÄúMn.‚Äù

‚ÄúI want at least three songs written about me,‚Äù Wei Wuxian requests. ‚ÄúMake sure they mention my beauty, not just how strong and fearless I am. You don‚Äôt have to lie about it‚ÄîI‚Äôm modest too. Just say I was half as beautiful as the Second Jade of Lan, that makes me twice as beautiful as anyone else.‚Äù

Lan Wangji, through much experience, knows a ploy when he sees one. He is being provoked, into a scowl or a scoff or‚ÄîWei Wuxian probably hopes‚Äîthe elusive eye roll. He refuses to rise to the bait. 

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why you can‚Äôt die first,‚Äù Wei Wuxian is saying. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good at music, but you‚Äôre better. Okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúWei Ying,‚Äù Lan Wangji says, since the edge of his robe is dangling in the fire he‚Äôs just stoked. 

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says, patting out the stray sparks, tucking the robe safely beneath him. He doesn‚Äôt say thanks, but he nods, and then he bends down to check on Lan Wangji‚Äôs leg in the newly bright light. 

---- 

Lan Wangji is learning this about himself: he has had enough of caves for a lifetime. 

Wei Wuxian, for all of his self-professed boredom, appears to share none of this sentiment. He explores the cave with enthusiasm, wandering off and returning to their circle of light, faithfully reporting each finding in exhaustive detail, at length, often already mid-sentence by the time he returns to Lan Wangji by the fire.

There is a shallow pool in this chamber. There are no signs of fish; there might be snakes, he‚Äôll keep looking. There are definitely bats, which means the pool is not safe to drink‚Äîa fact he dwells on less than he does the squeaks and flaps of the little bats, so *cute,* Lan Zhan. 

There is plenty of firewood. There is no sign of an exit. The bodies are gone, which makes Lan Wangji‚Äôs eyes widen, even as Wei Wuxian decides this bodes well for them. If Xuanwu stuffs himself, he won‚Äôt need them as a meal. ‚ÄúI bet he‚Äôs just hungry, Lan Zhan. *You‚Äôd* be pissed off too if you‚Äôd gone hundreds of years without a good snack.‚Äù It‚Äôs only the second day of their fast, but this is close enough to the truth that Lan Wangji can‚Äôt dismiss it. 

This bodes well too: there *is* water. The Wen soldiers dropped flasks as they fled or fell, and Wei Wuxian gathers an armful, enough to last three or four days, more if they ration it strictly. There is medicine too‚ÄîWei Wuxian shakes him awake over that one, an incoherent story about a bottle that he‚Äôd lost and thought was gone but then finally found. Bleary, Lan Wangji accepts the two pills Wei Wuxian drops on his tongue, dutifully coughing them down with a sip of stale water. Wei Wuxian brushes his chin, then swallows one pill for himself. 

‚Äú‚Äîour cores,‚Äù Wei Wuxian is saying, something about the nourishment thereof. It‚Äôs not food, nor is it enough to fully quench the pain or the thirst, but after a while, Lan Wangji feels as if he could keep his eyes open for more than an hour at a time. The pain recedes slightly. It feels like pale spring sunlight inside him; not a surge of energy, but a glimmer‚Äîa hope.

‚ÄúKnew Wen Qing could help us,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says happily, and performs another small miracle: for the first time in days, he closes his eyes and his mouth, allowing them both a few moments of rest. 

---- 

‚ÄúHave you ever broken a bone? Before this time, I mean.‚Äù

Later that day, or the next. Time bleeds like the wound on Lan Wangji‚Äôs leg before it had clotted. Wei Wuxian claims to keep track, but then again he has claimed it would take only two days for rescue, forgetting their rescuers have no swords to maneuver. Or maybe he does remember, but won‚Äôt say anything, chastened from when he‚Äôd already stumbled over the fact that help won‚Äôt be forthcoming from Cloud Recesses. Perhaps they are both politely keeping up fictions. Lan Wangji, trying to discipline his mind away from worst-case scenarios, has found that to his dismay the constant chatter helps. 

‚ÄúMn,‚Äù he says, which Wei Wuxian interprets correctly as *no.*

‚ÄúReally? Not ever?‚Äù He is lying on his back, one arm folded beneath his head, idly twirling a stick through his fingertips. ‚ÄúI have, lots. It‚Äôs not so bad, once you get used to it.‚Äù

Lan Wangji cannot conceive of *getting used to* the kind of pain in his leg. He bears it, he ignores it when necessary, but the pain touches a deep core of anger inside of him, something that cannot stand to suffer injustice. 

‚ÄúI climbed lots of trees,‚Äù Wei Wuxian is explaining. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd sleep up there, then fall and break my arm. Once it was because Jiang Cheng threw me off a pier.‚Äù

Lan Wangji tries to conceive of that too, a brother who shows his affection with aggression. Picturing Xichen throwing him off a pier, he might as well picture Xichen cutting off his head. 

‚ÄúI‚Äôve gotten burned before too.‚Äù Wei Wuxian starts to hike up his skirt, then thinks better of it, dropping the fabric back down over, presumably, whatever scar lurks beneath. ‚ÄúI was old enough to know better, but shijie‚Äôs soup smelled so good, I tried to climb up to reach it and knocked the pot off the stove.‚Äù

*Old enough to know better should apply to everything that you do,* Lan Wangji refrains from saying. See, he can do politeness, and fictions. 

‚ÄúOnce,‚Äù he says, and then pauses.

Wei Wuxian, sometimes, knows when to wait out the pauses. He twirls the stick through a complicated series of loops, both of them watching his fingers. 

‚ÄúOnce,‚Äù Lan Wangji says again. ‚ÄúI slipped. With Bichen. I had only just begun training. It took weeks to heal.‚Äù

‚ÄúOoh, Lan Zhan.‚Äù Wei Wuxian flips over to face him, eyes bright with interest. ‚ÄúYou do have scars.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji says illogically. 

‚ÄúNo? It didn‚Äôt scar? Do you have secret medicines known only to the Lan?‚Äù

What Lan Wangji had meant was, *no, I won‚Äôt show you,* only to realize he hadn‚Äôt been asked. He blushes in the firelight that is too dim to show blushes.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says again. 

‚ÄúNo secret medicines? Oh.‚Äù Wei Wuxian looks disappointed. Then he brightens. ‚ÄúThat means you *do* have scars, though. You‚Äôre a man, Lan Zhan.‚Äù

*Manhood* does not constitute *scarring,* but Lan Wangji doesn‚Äôt feel like revisiting the headache of heroic gestures and pretty girls. ‚ÄúIt was an accident,‚Äù he says in clipped tones. 

‚ÄúOf course it was, but you don‚Äôt *tell* people that. You make up a good story. One where you‚Äôre brave and the hero.‚Äù

Lan Wangji tries to resist. He really does try to resist. ‚ÄúLike falling out of trees, or being thrown off a pier?‚Äù

Wei Wuxian‚Äôs face lights up the way only his face lights up when a worthy opponent bests him. ‚ÄúHa!‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúExactly. Or knocking pots off a stove.‚Äù

He is grinning, and waiting to see if Lan Wangji will join him. When he doesn‚Äôt, Wei Wuxian laughs, undaunted, and rolls back over to resume tossing the stick in the air. 

---- 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so boring. I‚Äôm so bored,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says for the third time that hour, as if this is Lan Wangji‚Äôs fault. 

The third day. Lan Wangji is reasonably sure of this, if only because of the hollow pains in his stomach, and the fact his leg can bear some weight. Wei Wuxian, sitting next to him, is tossing pebbles at a stick he‚Äôs stuck in the ground. He yawns hugely, then pouts when this too fails to get Lan Wangji‚Äôs attention.

‚ÄúLan Zhan,‚Äù he says. 

Lan Wangji, who has been trying to meditate‚Äîalbeit with modifications, as his leg doesn‚Äôt allow for his preferred lotus pose‚Äîchooses the one response that is sure to provoke Wei Wuxian. Silence. 

‚ÄúLan Zhan?‚Äù A pebble clicks. ‚ÄúLan Zhan.‚Äù

Lan Wangji waits for one more *Lan Zhan,* the one that stretches the last syllable into a whine, before he opens his eyes. 

‚ÄúDo you do this a lot?‚Äù Wei Wuxian asks, indicating Lan Wangji‚Äôs state of interrupted serenity, as if this was the urgent question that just had to be asked. 

Lan Wangji looks at him.

They both make a sound when their tongues touch. Heat floods odd places on Lan Wangji‚Äôs body‚Äîthe inside of his elbows, his thighs, the top of his scalp.

/private/cql/3-unclean-realm.title: Chapter 3 ‚Äî Unclean Realm
/private/cql/3-unclean-realm.content:
Wei Wuxian is dead. 

Two months, then three. That‚Äôs what people begin saying. 

*Beat him like a sandbag,* a Wen soldier boasts. Laughter. *Showed that arrogant brat.* Snap of a cord around a neck. 

Nobody has answers. Jin Zixuan says, *His sister says it isn‚Äôt like him‚Ä¶* Jiang Wanyin says, *We thought he went to Lanling for you.* 

It‚Äôs unthinkable, what else they say. Burial Mounds. No one survives it. Nobody returns from that place with body or soul intact, not even Wei Wuxian.

This is war, and that‚Äôs warfare: wild and unfounded rumors. Lan Wangji tells himself that. He holds out hope, he builds defenses. Becomes as stubborn as he has ever been in his life. Wei Wuxian would be proud. Wei Wuxian would call him a ridiculous person. Wei Wuxian would tackle him with exuberance, say, *Lan Zhan, I‚Äôm all right! What were you thinking, you really did all that for me?*

This is not what happens. 

This happens instead: Wen Chao dies, and Wei Wuxian lives. It‚Äôs Lan Wangji‚Äôs wildest dream, and it comes true like a nightmare. Like a ghost that stands before him in Wei Wuxian‚Äôs robes, alive in Wei Wuxian‚Äôs body, and not Wei Wuxian at all. 

*Who do you think you are?* this new Wei Wuxian asks him, dark eyes that don‚Äôt spark with laughter, a smile that doesn‚Äôt reach past his lips. *Second Young Master Lan. Hanguang-jun. Lan Wangji*‚Äîthe cold reversal of every intimacy that Wei Wuxian has ever given him. Malevolent energy so tangible it almost coils in the air. 

All Lan Wangji can think, in that moment and after, through the turmoil and betrayal: 

*Who are* you? *Wei Ying, what on earth have you done?*

---- 

It is an artful performance‚Äîno wonder Lan Wangji endures an excruciating week of believing it.

He takes grim solace in the guqin. Wei Wuxian is hailed a hero. ‚ÄúLan Wangji,‚Äù he says politely whenever they cross each other‚Äôs path, slid like a knife between his ribs. 

Rumors fly that they‚Äôre fighting, but it‚Äôs nothing so clear cut as a fight, it‚Äôs just confusion and distance. Lan Wangji craves a fight, fights make Wei Wuxian *smile,* a clash of swords like a dance except Wei Wuxian won‚Äôt even carry Suibian around with him, not even to deflect suspicion.

‚ÄúYoung Master Wei has always been difficult,‚Äù Xichen notes wryly. (Xichen, who has returned himself, also changed, also more polite than ever, a new shadow in his eyes.)

It‚Äôs more than Lan Wangji can bear. He sits awake in the tender, bruised-purple hour before dawn, calming his mind with meditation, when the tiny splinter of a thought finally pushes to the fore. 

Everything about this feels familiar. Cool silence, cutting words‚Äîit‚Äôs Lan Wangji‚Äôs own tactics, turned against him. How he tried to survive it, that interminable summer in Cloud Recesses, in so deep over his head he couldn‚Äôt see a way out. Or the long days in Qishan, needing to keep Wei Wuxian out of harm‚Äôs way, desperately feigning indifference while Wen Chao stalked them like a wolf. 

Whatever Wei Wuxian has done‚Äîhe is trying to guard Lan Wangji from it. Or whatever has been done to him‚Äîhe is trying to stubbornly survive it himself. 

Which is just‚Ä¶ fuck, it‚Äôs *just like him.* Noble and *stupid* and it‚Äôs all Lan Wangji can do to not fly across the compound, drag him out of bed, throttle sense into him until Wei Wuxian capitulates and gives him the *truth.* 

He is more subtle than that, in the end‚Äîalthough not by much. If Wei Wuxian wants to play by old tactics, then Lan Wangji will give him old tactics. He pulls Bichen, drives him back with a flurry of his most vicious sword work. It feels *right,* like a kiss, to land the blade at his throat.

It works. It‚Äôs their old language, provocation and combat, the calling of each other‚Äôs bluff. Lan Wangji‚Äôs heart sings like the blade he drops back in its sheath as Wei Wuxian finally, *finally,* sweet as a taste of cool water, meets Lan Wangji‚Äôs gaze, like the Wei Wuxian he knows.

---- 

They talk, on the rooftop. The first tentative forging of a new path between them. There are still acres of terrain that Wei Wuxian is avoiding‚ÄîLan Wangji lets him. He has every intention of not giving up, of plying trust out of him the way Wei Wuxian plied him first, with friendship, with relentless, dogged endurance, not content until Lan Wangji was malleable clay in his hands. 
It‚Äôs not enough, and it‚Äôs a start. The first green shoot of spring after a desolate winter. Lan Wangji would stay there all night; it‚Äôs Wei Wuxian who leaves. *Yes,* he agrees, though, to Lan Wangji‚Äôs offer of help. Wicked tricks, crafty tricks, Lan Wangji isn‚Äôt sure the semantics matter. It‚Äôs just like Wei Wuxian to go and do something rash, but whatever he‚Äôs done, Lan Wangji can believe that he had his reasons, and they can solve it together. 
Back in his rooms, Xichen appears in the doorway as Lan Wangji plays the qin. He stands there quietly, listening for a while until Lan Wangji moves through the coda, resting his hands on the strings instead of looping the melody endlessly again. 
‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt heard that piece before,‚Äù Xichen says, and something soft twinges in Lan Wangji‚Äôs chest‚Äîhow long they have been apart; how much has changed for him without his brother‚Äôs knowledge. It feels disloyal, almost, to hold secrets from him. To not disclose what has happened, where part of his loyalties lie. 
‚ÄúMn,‚Äù is all he says. 
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs lovely. May I join you?‚Äù
Lan Wangji assents. His brother draws out Liebing, and the sudden association of a flute makes Lan Wangji pause. After a moment, he asks‚Äîare there Lan temperament techniques he might not be aware of, more advanced methods than the ones he was taught? 
‚ÄúPerhaps,‚Äù Xichen says thoughtfully. ‚ÄúIf we‚Ä¶‚Äù He trails off, unable to finish the sentence. *If we return to Cloud Recesses‚Ä¶ if it‚Äôs rebuilt, if those texts still exist‚Ä¶* ‚ÄúI will see what I can find for you,‚Äù he says, and offers Lan Wangji a wan smile. 

---- 

Lan Wangji slips back into the background, ceding Xichen his rightful place as the head of the clan. He is more than happy to do it. Leadership doesn‚Äôt suit him; too much finesse is needed, a level of political tact that is quite frankly beyond him. He still attends the long meetings, the endless hours of plotting strategy, but only as an auxiliary. No one looks to him to speak, which is a relief, especially when tempers flare, the strain wearing them down the way a millstone grinds charcoal into a fuel that needs only a spark to ignite. 
Jiang Wanyin is just as ill-suited for the role, both deferential and belligerent, wearing his newfound authority like an ill-fitting cloak. 
He clashes with Wei Wuxian daily. It becomes a common occurrence to hear one or both of their voices rising, bouncing off the courtyard walls. Lan Wangji, if he‚Äôs in earshot, places himself nearby, in case Wei Wuxian should wish for an escape. It irks Jiang Wanyin, who‚Äôs regained his old habit of scowling at Lan Wangji for the mere fact of his existence, their uneasy truce collapsing. 
‚ÄúHe‚Äôs just worried,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says after one of their spats, sounding tired, sounding restless, falling into his old habit too of defending his brother. ‚ÄúShijie says he‚Äôs not sleeping.‚Äù
‚ÄúAre you?‚Äù Lan Wangji asks. 
‚ÄúHa! Me? Lan Zhan. I sleep *too much,* like a baby. You can‚Äôt even wake me in the mornings.‚Äù
It‚Äôs a lie, and a transparent one. Lan Wangji rises before dawn, and too often now he finds Wei Wuxian awake during those hours, prowling around on some errand or toying with notes on his flute. ‚ÄúOh no,‚Äù Wei Wuxian says, whenever Lan Wangji appears in whatever tucked-away corner where he‚Äôs failed to hide himself. ‚ÄúYoung Master Lan is here to scold me.‚Äù
Lan Wangji does not. He unwraps pancakes, or fruit, or stolen cakes from the kitchens, and sits down beside him, sharing the small meal in silence, usually while a rosy dawn breaks. He‚Äôs tamed wild rabbits; the principle is not all that different, with the right application of patience and rewards they eat out of his hands.

/private/cql/6-burial-mounds.title: Chapter 6 ‚Äî Burial Mounds
/private/cql/6-burial-mounds.content:
> *In which of course Wei Wuxian has somehow acquired a child when he‚Äôs supposed to be busy raising armies of corpses.* 
---

One month. In that way, it‚Äôs easier this time‚Äîit was in Yiling where Wei Wuxian went missing before, presumed dead for three months, and now it has only been one. Not dead, not missing, but cut off from the cultivation world like an unwelcome limb.

Lan Wangji is with Xichen the day the letter arrives. Xichen unfolds it, reading in silence for several long minutes without changing his expression. 

‚ÄúBrother,‚Äù Lan Wangji says, when he can stand it no longer. 

Brushwork that elegant, paper that fine; it can only be from Lanling. Xichen looks up, relaying Jin Guangyao‚Äôs account of how he has been working day and night in preparation for the wedding. 

That is not Lan Wangji‚Äôs concern. ‚ÄúAnd?‚Äù he says. 

An infinitesimal pause; an infinitesimal shake of his head. ‚ÄúHe won‚Äôt be attending,‚Äù Xichen says. ‚ÄúThey thought it prudent‚Ä¶ not to inform him.‚Äù

Birds flit in the autumn-bright branches around them, unaffected by the news, by the petty, bloodless cruelties humans will inflict on each other. *Not inform him.* It‚Äôs only the marriage of the person he loves most in the world. (To the person he despises most in the world.) Jiang Yanli is not behind this, of that at least Lan Wangji is certain. 

‚ÄúHe should know,‚Äù Lan Wangji says, trying to keep his voice neutral. 

Xichen does not disagree. ‚ÄúBut that is for his clan, and the Jins‚Ä¶ it is not our place to say.‚Äù 

Not their place. The blood feud between the Jins and the Wen refugees‚Äînot their place. Cultivators killed, Wei Wuxian exiled‚Äînot their place. 

‚ÄúWangji,‚Äù Xichen says, warning. ‚ÄúIt wouldn‚Äôt be wise, if you wrote to inform him.‚Äù 

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Lan Wangji agrees. 

‚ÄúPromise me that you won‚Äôt.‚Äù 

‚ÄúWrite to him? I won‚Äôt,‚Äù Lan Wangji says.

---- 

Yiling buzzes like a wasp‚Äôs nest. It‚Äôs almost comforting, really‚ÄîWei Wuxian must be nearby.

The intensity of the rumors, the wild distortions, are worse here than in Gusu. Yiling-laozhu, they‚Äôve started calling him, the kind of puerile game one doesn‚Äôt always outgrow in childhood, creating monsters or villains in order to play the hero. Lan Wangji can only imagine how much Wei Wuxian is feeding these rumors himself, entertained by the tales. This isn‚Äôt supposed to be a *game.* 

Every teahouse, every tavern, has a variation of the tale, each more outlandish than the last. Of course it‚Äôs not only that‚Äîother minor rumors and dramas still grip the populace too. But that‚Äôs what Lan Wangji‚Äôs ear is tuned for, and so that is what he hears. 

Ghouls and demons‚Äîno, fierce corpses! *Armies* of the dead. Virgin orgies; infant sacrifices. *If anything, Wei Wuxian would not be that organized,* Lan Wangji thinks wryly, would tell anyone who would listen. 

Nobody is interested in the truth. The lies that bother him most are the ones that most closely echo what was said in Jinlintai. Wei Wuxian is a traitor; Wei Wuxian is mediocre at best; if not for the mercy of the Jiangs he‚Äôd be on the streets where he belongs, and look what he‚Äôs done to repay them. 

Or‚Äîworst of all: someone like him doesn‚Äôt deserve to live.

It‚Äôs that last one that drives Lan Wangji out of the teahouse into Yiling‚Äôs bustling main street. The harsh glare of sunlight, stares from the crowd. A tiny, dusty child in brown robes who collides with Lan Wangji‚Äôs legs, depositing himself at his feet. 

Lan Wangji stares down. The little boy clings like a limpet, a bright-eyed grin that says no one has taught him this is not a proper thing to do. ‚ÄúNo‚Ä¶?‚Äù Lan Wangji says, afraid it comes out like a question. Of the two of them, he‚Äôs not the one who bursts into tears. 

---

*This* is your fearsome Yiling-laozhu, Lan Wangji thinks more than once, once he is able to think. 

It is a heartstopping sight, Wei Wuxian parting the crowds like the clouds that can‚Äôt hide the sun. Collecting the boy by the hand‚Äîbecause of course Wei Wuxian has somehow acquired a *child* when he‚Äôs supposed to be busy raising armies of corpses. Drying his tears, dusting his robes. Swordfighting with toys in the street, flying paper-winged butterflies, the two of them turning twin grins upon him like they are *trying* to stop Lan Wangji‚Äôs heart.

This is the Wei Wuxian he knows. The undimmed sunlight of him, none of the fury from Lanling, or the cold and miserable distance the last time he reappeared from the dead. He is changed‚Äîstill, again‚Äîfrighteningly thin and shabbily dressed‚Äîbut the old goodness shines through him, scrubbed clean and unclouded, at ease with himself in a way that Lan Wangji has not seen in a very long time. 

He feels mauled by it, this unexpected turn of events, so far outside his experience that all he can do is be himself, slightly stiff, slightly bitchy, warm all over when that‚Äôs the Lan Wangji these two accept unequivocally, delighted with him, laying claim to him as easily as they do with each other.
